reasoning: [Specific Program Not Verified] Paper mentions 'Livelihood Empowerment Against Poverty (LEAP)' but search could not confirm this as graduation program: Perplexity search result: The Livelihood Empowerment Against Poverty (LEAP) program in Ghana is a flagship social protection program providing unconditional cash transfers to extremely poor households, including the elderly, persons with severe disabilities, orphans, and pregnant or lactating mothers. There is clear evidence from multiple sources, including the official LEAP site and program evaluations, that the main intervention is cash grants provided regularly to targeted households[1][2][3][5][6][7]. The goal of LEAP is primarily to alleviate short-term poverty, improve access to health and education, and encourage behavioral change toward productive activities. However, there is no evidence in official or evaluation reports that LEAP disburses productive assets (such as livestock, tools, or direct livelihood inputs) to beneficiaries, nor is it described as a comprehensive 'graduation' program of the BRAC type combining sequenced supports like skills training, asset transfer, and coaching. While LEAP may, in some cases, offer referrals or promote long-term welfare, it lacks the multi-component structure that characterizes graduation programs. | Graduation: NO, Cash: YES, Assets: NO | Confidence: HIGH | Sources: https://transfer.cpc.unc.edu/countries/ghana/, https://www.ssph-journal.org/journals/international-journal-of-public-health/articles/10.3389/ijph.2023.1605336/full, http://akatsinorth.gov.gh/reassessment-of-the-leap-program/
